title-group.article-title: Transesophageal Echocardiography–Guided Hemodynamic Assessment and Management

author-notes.corresp: Harold M. Hastings, PhD, ImaCor Inc, 839 Stewart Avenue, Suite 3, Garden City, NY 11530, USA; e-mail: hhastings@imacorinc.com.

abstract.p: Hemodynamic instability (shock) poses a major challenge in intensive care and is associated with increased mortality, morbidity, length of stay, and costs. The purpose of hemodynamic assessment and management is to detect the cause of hemodynamic instability in a given patient, provide actionable information for the physician, and thus help guide the management and resolution of hemodynamic instability. Although transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) has been the gold standard for hemodynamic assessment and management in the cardiac operating room, the invasive nature of conventional TEE has limited its use as a management tool in intensive care. Instead, one has seen a variety of indirect hemodynamic monitors used, despite now well understood limitations as described in a previous Critical Conversation in the July 2011 issue of this journal. Here we describe the use of TEE in intensive care as well as a new TEE system (the ImaCor hTEE system, ImaCor, Garden City, NY) with a miniaturized (approximately nasogastric tube sized), indwelling probe designed specifically for TEE-guided hemodynamic assessment and management in intensive care (hemodynamic TEE).

disp-quote.p: “One of the major challenges in intensive care is to maintain adequate cardiac output and perfusion.”

body.p: The purpose of this article is to describe hemodynamic assessment and monitoring with transesophageal echocardiography (hemodynamic TEE) and the enabling technology as a follow-on to a previous published Critical Conversation roundtable on hemodynamic monitoring.1 One of the major challenges in intensive care is to maintain adequate cardiac output and perfusion. The problem has been clearly stated by Marik et al2:

The cornerstone of treating patients with shock remains as it has for decades: intravenous fluids. Surprisingly, dosing intravenous fluid during resuscitation from shock remains largely empirical. Too little fluid may result in tissue hypoperfusion and worsen organ dysfunction; however, over-prescription of fluid appears also to impede oxygen delivery and compromise patient outcome. Recent data suggest that early aggressive resuscitation of critically ill patients may limit and/or reverse tissue hypoxia, progression to organ failure and improve outcome.2,3

This quote captures a typical challenge in hemodynamic management. It is well known that cardiac output (CO) is the product of heart rate and stroke volume (SV), that SV itself depends on preload (delivery of adequate volume to the left ventricle), contractility, and afterload, and that preload depends on many factors, including volume and right ventricular function, which can be assessed by TEE4 (Figure 1). These factors, which are complexly interrelated, need to be evaluated in a dynamic, iterative way to accurately diagnose and treat critically ill patients.

body.p: Reduced CO arising from reduced SV may be because of decreased preload, increased afterload, or decreased contractility, or a combination. Without additional information, it is difficult to diagnose the cause of low SV, and thus determine the appropriate treatment such as additional volume to increase preload, vasodilators to reduce afterload, or inotropes to increase contractility. Typical relationships between physiological factors (eg, pressure–volume relationships) may add little information, since diseased states or surgery can alter normal cardiac function and patient physiology.4 Moreover, the wrong treatment can prove ineffective (eg, fluid administration to a nonresponsive patient) or even harmful.

In contrast, Colreavy et al5 found that TEE revealed the cause of hemodynamic instability accurately in 67% of hypotensive patients studied. When coupled with well-known algorithms for managing hemodynamic instability,2 a new and expanded role for TEE in diagnosing and treating hemodynamic instability in critically ill patients has begun to emerge.

sec.title: A Brief History of TEE in Hemodynamic Management in Intensive Care
sec.p: TEE, an indispensable monitor for the hemodynamic management of patients in the cardiac operating room, has a long history of use outside of the operating room in some major European hospitals. Early studies in the United States (Oh et al6 and Foster and Schiller7) found TEE safe and effective in critical care of 120 patients, with no fatalities, and no significant complications other than hemodynamic and respiratory worsening in 2 patients with heart failure. Khoury et al8 and Hwang et al9 reported management changes in half of critically ill patients; Poelaert et al10 found management changes in 44% of patients also monitored with a pulmonary artery catheterization. Slama et al11 concluded that TEE was safe and useful in managing patients with unexplained shock, hypoxemia, or suspected endocarditis. They identified major diagnostic changes requiring immediate action in 20% of patients and other major changes in another 13% with high interobserver diagnostic concordance (84%).11 Other groups found similar results, that is, that TEE revealed the cause of hemodynamic instability in 67% of hypotensive patients studied.5,12 Costachescu et al13 found better interobserver agreement for first diagnosis by TEE than for other hemodynamic monitors. Other TEE studies discovered significant left ventricular dysfunction in septic shock12 and significant preload defect after fluid loading in severe sepsis.14 More generally, Hüttemann’s15 2006 review of the effectiveness of TEE in 2508 critical care patients found significant diagnostic, therapeutic, and surgical impact on management; therapeutic impact averaged 36%.15,16 Further study beyond the large body of change of management studies will be needed to develop and assess appropriate algorithms for TEE in intensive care.
Vieillard-Baron et al17 developed a standard bedside TEE exam for managing hemodynamics in septic shock. In their article, they describe the basic hemodynamic TEE exam:

disp-quote.p: by transesophageal echocardiography, a long-axis view permits examination of the four cardiac cavities. From this view we measure left ventricular (LV) and right ventricular (RV) end-diastolic and end-systolic size and calculate the LV ejection fraction . . . A short-axis view of both ventricles by a transgastric . . . approach also permits measurement of LV size, calculation of LV fractional area contraction, and examination of septal shape and kinetics. (Thirdly), a long-axis view of the superior vena cava, anastomosing with the right atrium, allows us to examine variation in its diameter during the respiratory cycle.

sec.p: Figure 2 (next page) displays static pictures of these views using the ImaCor hTEE system. The authors go on,

disp-quote.p: depression of left ventricular (LV) contractility is constant in patients with septic shock. Because most parameters of cardiac function are strongly dependent on afterload, especially in this context, the cardiac performance evaluated at the bedside reflects intrinsic contractility, but also the degree of vasoplegia.18

sec.p: Thus, “septic cardiac dysfunction was largely underestimated because the hemodynamic device used, i.e., the pulmonary artery catheter, was not appropriate for establishing such a diagnosis.” The shortcomings of other methods of measuring hemodynamics as pointing out in this study have spurred the development of a TEE device more easily tolerated by critically ill patients.

sec.title: Safety and Training
sec.p: The benefits of TEE must be balanced against its risks. The risks of (conventional) TEE are well known, with a reported 0.2% to 0.5% incidence of major complications and estimated mortality of <0.01% in approximately 30 000 patients.19-24 Two large studies reported an average esophageal perforation risk of 0.02%.23,24 Reported risks in 7 studies involving 600 ICU patients appear similar, with an overall 1% risk of transient arrhythmias and hypotension, and estimated mortality <0.01%.5-8,11,19,25 Krishnamoorthy et al26 recently reported on 72-hour management of an ICU case with a Phillips TEE probe (Philips Medical Systems, Bothel, WA) in place between exams. These authors also cited the miniaturized probe described below.

Benjamin et al27 described the successful training of intensivists to perform focused TEE exams aired at cardiac filling and function; the growing use of TEE in intensive care has led to numerous recent articles on training and accreditation.28-32

sec.title: TEE in Intensive Care With a Recent Hemodynamic TEE system
sec.p: TEE-guided hemodynamic management (hemodynamic TEE) in intensive care may be obtained with a recently produced miniaturized, disposable, detachable monoplane probe (the ImaCor hTEE probe, 5.5 mm diameter, approximately the size of an 18 French nasogastric tube). This device has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for indwelling use in a patient for up to 72 hours. The system is designed to allow on-demand, episodic hemodynamic assessment for hemodynamic management of multiple critical care patients with a single machine. This particular probe can achieve 15 cm penetration at 6.67 MHz (B-mode). The system records 50 frames per second cine loops and 30 frames per second colorflow loops.

Unlike conventional TEE, hemodynamic TEE is a limited focused exam assessment of cardiac filling and function using the 3 views described above by Vieillard-Baron et al.17 It is worth noting that in addition to assessing preload and contractility, key components of cardiac output, these views can be used to detect effusion, tamponade, and obstruction.

Early users have reported on hemodynamic TEE with this system in the cardiac ICU33,34 for patients undergoing therapeutic hypothermia for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest35,36 and for orthotopic liver transplantation.37 Moreover, a meta-analysis of early experience found substantially the same therapeutic impact as reported by Hüttemann for conventional TEE, that is, that hemodynamic TEE led to changes in fluid and vasoactive drug management in 45% of patients studied, and avoided reoperation in 10% of post–cardiac surgery patients studied.38 Finally, Vincent et al4 identified TEE as a useful component for managing hemodynamic instability in critical care. Further study will be needed to determine whether and how well this hemodynamic TEE package fills that need in the ICU.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: TEE has been identified by Vincent et al4 as a useful component in managing hemodynamic instability in critical care. Further study will be needed to determine whether and how well this hemodynamic TEE package fills that need in the ICU.
